column4: does anyone know the command to connect to a wireless network?
can someone give the command to connect or reconnect to a wireless network
It depends.  man iwconfig will connect you to an access point, and you can give it your key if it's WEP.  If you use WPA, you need wpa_supplicant.  To handle dhcp, you need dhclient.
How long did you wait?  And what are the specs for your computer?
What is the problem?
Last I saw, someone asked you to verify the md5 hash.  Did you?
That sounds bad.  Can you pastebin the command you typed and the output you got?
I just put md5sum /dev/cdrom and then got md5sum: /dev/cdrom" Imput/output error

Ah.  You have to do md5sum on the file you downloaded.  You have to go to the computer you used to download the ISO file (that you used to burn the CD), and then do the md5sum there.  It should be something like: "md5sum xubuntu.iso".
I did it and this is what I got: xubuntu-10.04-desktop-i386.iso) = 7f064bc012025a5307ef6d81b0bc4c87
also i burned the iso at about 6x speed, could that be the problem?
Compare that to https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UbuntuHashes
I found it in that page but I'm not sure what I'm supposed to do
If the 7f064bc... (called the md5 hash or md5 sum) matches, then it means the file you downloaded is correct (doesn't have any errors).
It's a way to make sure that the problems you're having aren't because your downloaded ISO has errors.
okay so the iso looks good, could the problem be that I burned at 6x speed?
last time i had no problem installing from xubuntu 9.4 and I burned that at 10x speed
I don't think so.  I would guess that it's hardware issues that are causing your install to hang.  But I really don't know.
Sorry I can't help.
so you think my hardware just cant handle 10.4 and one more question, could the installation just be taking a long time to start, does that ever happened?
I waited about 5 to 8 minutes, and my specs are Pentium 4 1.6  and 256 Ram
It shouldn't take that long.  What I meant by hardware issues was a bug in detecting your hardware, or a bug in a driver being used.  Not that your computer is too slow to run Xubuntu.
well thanks for your help, i guess I'm stuck with 9.04 :(
